Dear Ms. Oom:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.

ALLEGATION:
Facility has not submitted records to MDHHS for permanent retention one year
following the final order of adoption as required.
INVESTIGATION:
Chief Administrator was notified of new complainant via telephone on May 23, 2022.
Chief Administrator stated the Adoption Program Manager was at the agency and
she would notify her of my on-site visit.
Complainant was contacted via email on May 23, 2022. The email requested
additional information regarding the specific adoption files the agency did not submit
timely. Complainant responded via email on May 24, 2022, and provided details
regarding 2 adoption files that were not submitted timely.
2

Adoption Program Manager was interviewed face-to-face at the agency on May 23,
2022. Adoption Program Manager stated the agency received 2 emails that she is
aware of from DHS Central Office over the past few months indicating the agency
was overdue with sending adoption files. The most recent email was in February.
Adoption Program Manager stated the emails were not sent directly to her and had
been forwarded to her. Adoption Program Manager stated the emails were originally
sent to the agency’s Chief Financial Officer who had requested the Adoption
Program Manager be included in the emails. Adoption Program Manager stated
there was a delay from the time the CFO received the emails until they were
forwarded to the Adoption Program Manager. Adoption Program Manager stated the
agency responded to the emails and indicated the date the files were sent and did
not receive a response after that. Adoption Program Manager stated the 2 emails
referenced different files and a few of the files did not belong to their agency.
Adoption Program Manager stated the agency will provide the files to the
appropriate DHS office that was involved with the particular case. She stated the
agency will either hand deliver the file or mail it depending on the distance. Adoption
Program Manager stated she will send an email to support staff within the agency
one year after the adoption finalization and indicate what files need to be hand
delivered or mailed. The support staff handles the cases involved with Kent Co DHS
and agency adoption workers will arrange to hand deliver or mail files to other
county DHS offices. Adoption Program Manager stated the agency will request
written confirmation from the local DHS office when files are hand delivered.
Adoption Program Manager was sent a follow up email on May 24, 2022, to provide
additional details regarding the new complaint. Youth A and Youth B’s adoption
finalization dates were provided to Adoption Program Manager. Adoption Program
Manager stated their agency was not involved in Youth B’s adoption. Adoption
Program Manager stated she would provide verification of the date Youth A’s
adoption file was mailed to St. Clair Co. DHS.
Documents Reviewed:
 MISACWIS Case File: Youth A’s adoption finalization order was signed on
October 20, 2020.
 MISACWIS Case File: Youth B’s adoption finalization information was
reviewed and verified another agency had case responsibility.
 Cover sheet agency provided to St. Clair Co. DHS indicating adoption records
are being provided per adoption policy. Sheet is signed by agency staff as
well as St. Clair Co DHS staff and date stamped April 25, 2022, as being
received via drop box/US mail by St. Clair Co. DHS.
3

APPLICABLE RULE
ADM 1030 Adoption case record retention
For both MDHHS and contracted adoption agency cases, the
local MDHHS office or contracted agency must retain all
adoption case records for one year after finalization of the
adoption. One year (between 12-13 months) past the adoption
finalization date, a contracted adoption agency must send the
original record to the local MDHHS office; copies must not be
maintained by the contracted adoption agency; see licensing
rule R400.12713-Adoption Placement Record.
ANALYSIS: The agency did not send original adoption records to the local
MDHHS office within 12-13 months after finalization of adoption
as required. The adoption finalization of Youth A occurred on
October 20, 2020, and the agency provided verification the
adoption file was provided to St. Clair Co. DHS on April 25,
2022.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
I recommend upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan no change be
made to the license status of this child placing agency.
